person_115.name: Moses
person_115.description: According to the Old Testament Hebrew prophet who is considered the most important prophet in Judaism and one of the most important prophets in Christianity and other religions.

person_406.name: Alfred
person_406.description: King of the West Saxons from 871 to 886, and King of the Anglo-Saxons from 886 until his death in 899.

person_407.name: George III
person_407.description: King of Great Britain and Ireland from 1760 until his death in 1820 who had a strong interest in science. RoyalFellowRSL.

person_269.name: LuigiGalvani
person_269.description: Italian surgeon and anatomist who carried out experiments with electricity and animals. The term 'galvanism' was named after him

person_199.name: AlessandroVolta
person_199.description: Professor of experimental physics at the University of Pavia. At the end of the eighteenth century he Invented the Voltaic pile which produced electric current and which Davy shortly dubbed the battery. Davy described meeting him in 1814 in notebook 14/I, p.38. ForMemRSL.

person_226.name: ThomasThomson
person_226.description: Scottish chemist and mineralogist whose writings contributed to the early spread of Dalton's atomic theory. FRSL.

person_150.name: William HydeWollaston
person_150.description: Originally a physician he became a prominent chemist, physicist and physiologist isolating the chemical elements osmium, palladium and rhodium. He made his fortune by developing a method of obtaining metallic platinum. A friend and to some extent a rival of Davy's, in 1820 he served briefly as President of the Royal Society of London between Banks's death and Davy's election. FRSL.

person_286.name: CharlesRoyce
person_286.description: Assisted Royal Institution lecturers, including Davy, bewteen 1802 and 1808.

person_643.name: RobertSmith
person_643.description: From 1797 first Baron Carrington (in the British peerage), was until then an MP. An early Royal Institution Proprietor he heavily involved in the Board of Agriculture serving as President from 1798 until 1803 in which role he negotiated Davy's lectures there. FRSL.

person_654.name: GeorgeSpencer
person_654.description: From 1758, 4th Duke of Marlborough. British courtier, nobleman and politician. FRSL.

person_640.name: SamuelPurkis
person_640.description: A friend of Davyâ€™s friends S. T. Coleridge and Thomas Poole and the owner of a tannery at Brentford, Middlesex.

person_105.name: ThomasPoole
person_105.description: Tanner based in Nether Stowey, philanthropist and essayist; a friend of Davy and Coleridge.

person_090.name: Marc-AugustePictet
person_090.description: Genevan natural philosopher and journal editor. Corresponded with Davy. ForMemRSL.

place_021.name: Cornwall
place_021.description: Cornwall is a county in south-west England, birthplace of Humphry Davy.

place_509.name: Lizard Point
place_509.description: The Lizard is a peninsula of the southern coast of Cornwall. It is the most southerly point of the British mainland. The geology of the Lizard is complex: it contains some of Cornwall's oldest (Precambrian) rocks, as well as heavily metamorphosed rocks.

place_014.name: Marazion
place_014.description: Marazion is a civil parish and town, on the shore of Mount's Bay in Cornwall.

place_071.name: London
place_071.description: The capital city of England and the United Kingdom.

place_006.name: Penzance
place_006.description: Penzance is a town, civil parish, and port in the Penwith district of Cornwall, and Davy's birthplace.
